DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the neuroblastoma low stroma histology.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A neuroblastic tumor characterized by the presence of neuroblastic cells, the absence of ganglion cells, and the absence of a prominent Schwannian stroma formation._The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Neuroblastoma is a specific type of neuroblastic tumor which is characterized by the presense of neuroblastic cells forming groups or nests separated by delicate stromal septa without prominent Schwannian stroma. (Adapted from WHO.)

Concepts.definition: A malignant neuroblastic tumor characterized by the presence of neuroblastic cells, the absence of ganglion cells, and the absence of a prominent Schwannian stroma formation.

Property.preferredDefinition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

Concepts.definition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree, intensity or amount._The non-neoplastic connective tissue of an organ._The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Patients of any age with stroma-poor tumors, undifferentiated or differentiated neuroblasts, and a mitosis-karyorrhexis index of more than 200; or patients older than 18 months with stroma-poor tumors, undifferentiated neuroblasts, and a mitosis-karyorrhexis index of 100-200; or patients older than 60 months with stroma-poor tumors, differentiated neuroblasts, and a mitosis-karyorrhexis index of less than 100.

Concepts.definition: Patients of any age with stroma-poor tumors, undifferentiated or differentiated neuroblasts, and a mitosis-karyorrhexis index of more than 200; or patients older than 18 months with stroma-poor tumors, undifferentiated neuroblasts, and a mitosis-karyorrhexis index of 100-200; or patients older than 60 months with stroma-poor tumors, differentiated neuroblasts, and a mitosis-karyorrhexis index of less than 100.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Patients of any age with stroma-rich tumors and no nodular pattern; or patients younger than 18 months with stroma-poor tumors, a mitosis-karyorrhexis index of less than 200, and differentiated or undifferentiated neuroblasts; or patients younger than 60 months with stroma-poor tumors, a mitosis-karyorrhexis index of less than 100, and well-differentiated neuroblasts.

Concepts.definition: Patients of any age with stroma-rich tumors and no nodular pattern; or patients younger than 18 months with stroma-poor tumors, a mitosis-karyorrhexis index of less than 200, and differentiated or undifferentiated neuroblasts; or patients younger than 60 months with stroma-poor tumors, a mitosis-karyorrhexis index of less than 100, and well-differentiated neuroblasts.

In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree, intensity or amount.
The non-neoplastic connective tissue of an organ.

The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
